question_details.query: What actions are available to encourage natural foraging behaviours in captive primates?
What are the potential benefits and negative impacts of using complex feeding devices, like puzzle feeders or prey simulators, for captive primates and carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For captive primates, puzzle feeders have been associated with increased foraging behaviour and tool use, and more time spent feeding with less time inactive, but also decreased food sharing and increased aggression [1318]. For captive carnivores, providing live invertebrate prey (including via feeding devices) increased explorative behaviours in fennec foxes [1926]. Prey-simulating devices (e.g., lures, pulleys, bungees) increased activity levels and behavioural diversity in felids, with pacing decreasing and walking increasing in cougars; however, pacing initially increased in tigers when provided with a carcass on a bungee [1927].
summary_statements: For captive primates, puzzle feeders have been associated with increased foraging behaviour and tool use.
Puzzle feeders for captive primates have been associated with more time spent feeding and less time being inactive.
Puzzle feeders for captive primates have been associated with decreased food sharing and increased aggression.
Providing live invertebrate prey, including via feeding devices, increased explorative behaviours in captive fennec foxes.
Prey-simulating devices increased activity levels and behavioural diversity in felids.
The use of prey-simulating devices led to decreased pacing and increased walking in cougars.
Pacing initially increased in tigers when tigers were provided with a carcass on a bungee.

question_details.query: In a zoo environment, what are the documented effects of altering the timing and predictability of feeding schedules for captive primates and carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For primates, one replicated controlled study found that shifting to unpredictable feeding schedules decreased inactivity in chimpanzees [1338]. For carnivores, unpredictable or random temporal feeding schedules reduced stereotypic pacing in tigers and cheetahs according to multiple replicated studies, increased territorial behavior in coyotes without affecting traveling or foraging in one replicated before-and-after controlled study, and increased behavioral diversity in red foxes and alertness in a black-footed cat in before-and-after studies [1904]. No studies were found that directly tested altering feeding schedules in relation to visitor activity or the use of automated feeders for carnivores [1914, 1913].

question_details.query: What are the alternatives to feeding processed or commercial pellet diets to captive primates and carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For primates, identified alternatives include presenting whole foods rather than chopped or processed items, which increased amount consumed and time spent feeding in macaques [1323]; offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed, which increased feeding time and reduced inactivity in rhesus macaques [1335]; providing cut branches (browse), with captive gorillas using wild-like processing skills when given stinging nettles [1332]; providing nectar (including artificial nectar), for which no direct quantitative evidence on effects was captured [1331]; and installing live vegetation in planters for foraging, which increased time spent foraging by chimpanzees compared to browse/grass with the normal diet [1327]. For carnivores, alternatives include feeding whole carcasses (with or without organs/gastrointestinal tract), which reduced pacing in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars but increased pacing in tigers; in cheetahs, whole rabbit was associated with lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A than supplemented beef and with lower inflammatory bowel indicators; in ocelots and African wildcats, whole young chickens had lower digestible energy/fat and lower organic matter digestibility than commercial or ground-chicken diets [1901]; feeding a plant-derived protein diet, which increased digestible energy and dry matter digestibility but decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine in maned wolves compared to (supplemented) animal-based protein diets [1903]; allocating fast days, which was associated with more pacing on non-feeding days in large felids fed once every three days [1906]; supplementing meat-based diets with vitamins or minerals (no direct quantitative evidence captured) [1907]; and altering food abundance or type seasonally (no direct quantitative evidence captured) [1910].

question_details.query: What dietary modifications are available to better reflect the natural feeding ecology of captive primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Available dietary-related modifications include: providing cut browse such as stinging nettles, which elicited wild-like processing skills in captive gorillas [1332]; planting live vegetation (e.g., rye grass) and scattering seeds in planters to increase time spent foraging [1327]; presenting foods whole rather than chopped, which increased amount consumed and time feeding in macaques [1323]; offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed, which increased feeding time and reduced inactivity in rhesus macaques [1335]; supplying live invertebrate prey, which reduced inactivity and increased foraging to levels seen in wild loris [1333]; providing access to food at all times (day and night), for which no evidence of effects was captured [1340]; providing nectar (including artificial nectar), for which no evidence of effects was captured [1331]; changing the number of feeds per day, which increased feeding time in chimpanzees but was associated with increased hair eating in baboons [1337]; adding gum solutions to drilled hollow feeders, for which no evidence of effects was captured [1326]; and providing food at natural (wild) feeding times, for which no evidence of effects was captured [1339].

question_details.query: Within captive breeding programs for amphibians, what are the non-hormonal alternatives for simulating a breeding season to encourage reproduction?
To reduce aggression among primates housed in social groups, what are the most effective feeding-related interventions?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence indicates that scattering food throughout the enclosure reduced aggression in lemurs [1315], and feeding a fruit-free diet lowered aggression in lemurs [1329]. In contrast, presenting food in puzzle feeders increased aggression [1318]. No studies were found that directly tested the effects of feeding individuals separately on aggression or other outcomes [1342].

question_details.query: For captive lemurs and macaques, what are the most beneficial dietary changes to encourage naturalistic behaviours?
What are the trade-offs associated with different social feeding strategies for captive primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on feeding in social groups indicates: an enrichment task took less time to complete when monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone (replicated, controlled study, USA) [1343]; in the presence of groupmates, monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter (before-and-after study, Italy) [1343]. For feeding individuals separately, no evidence was captured on effects, so effectiveness or harmful impacts could not be assessed [1342].

question_details.query: What dietary management strategies are available for captive primates to reduce aggression and abnormal behaviours?
In a zoo setting, what are the potential benefits and harms of creating unpredictable feeding schedules for primates and carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For primates, feeding on unpredictable schedules was associated with decreased inactivity in chimpanzees [1338]. For carnivores, unpredictable feeding schedules reduced stereotypic pacing in tigers and cheetahs [1904], increased behavioural diversity in red foxes and alertness in a black-footed cat [1904], and increased territorial behaviour in coyotes while not affecting travelling or foraging [1904].

question_details.query: For captive felids in zoos, which food-based enrichment strategies are most effective for increasing activity levels and reducing pacing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for captive felids indicates that hiding food around the enclosure increases exploring and foraging, reduces stereotypic pacing in leopard cats, and reduces daytime sleeping in Canadian lynx [1915]. Presenting food frozen in ice increases activity and reduces abnormal or stereotypic behaviours in felids [1923]. In contrast, allocating fast days (feeding once every three days) led to more pacing on non-feeding days in large felids [1906].

question_details.query: For captive lemurs and macaques in a zoo setting, what methods of food presentation can increase foraging behaviours?
What are the known benefits and harms of using feeding devices that simulate prey or require manipulation for captive carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Benefits reported include increased activity and behavioural diversity in felids when presented with a lure or pulley system [1927], as well as increased exploratory and foraging behaviours and decreased stereotypic behaviours in sloth bears and spectacled bears when food was presented inside objects [1924]. Additional benefits noted were decreased pacing and increased walking in cougars when provided with a carcass on a bungee [1927]. Reported harms or negative outcomes include an initial increase in pacing in tigers when provided with a carcass on a bungee [1927], and a decrease in exploring/foraging behaviours in one sloth bear when presented with food inside objects [1924]. Neutral findings included grizzly bears spending a similar time manipulating food in a box and freely available food [1924].

question_details.query: Beyond dietary changes, what alternative husbandry actions can be taken in a captive setting to promote amphibian breeding success?
